The Parliament met at 9.30 a.m., MR. SPEAKER [THE HON. (DR.) JAGATH

( ) (The Hon. Speaker) I wish to announce that I have received the Decision of the Supreme Court in respect of the Bill titled Code of Criminal Procedure (Amendment), which had been challenged in the Supreme Court in terms of Article 121 (1) of the Constitution.

The Supreme Court, having considered the submissions, has held that there was no material to conclude that any of the provisions of the Bill violates any provision of the Constitution and accordingly, the Petitioner had informed the Court that the Petition will be withdrawn. Hence the Supreme Court had allowed to withdraw the Petition, terminated further proceedings and dismissed the Petition.
I order that the Decision of the Supreme Court be printed in the Official Report of todays Proceedings of the House.

ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS ( ) (The Hon. Speaker) -41]/2025- (2 ( .
CONSTRUCTION OF NEW LAW CHAMBERS IN KANDY:
asked the Minister of Justice and National Integration:
(i) whether he is aware that there are no chambers for new lawyers practising in courts in the Kandy District;
(ii) if so, the number of lawyers who have not had chambers so far, separately for each court in the Kandy District;
(iii) whether he is aware that steps have been taken to construct new law chambers on the land adjacent to the lawyers office complex established in Gatambe, Kandy;
(iv) whether he is aware that construction work pertaining to it has been stopped halfway;
(v) the measures that will be taken to expedite the construction work of the said new law chambers?
9 9 . You may have a good personal knowledge of this matter.
First, I must say that we are fully aware of the fact that there is an interdependence between a courthouse and the provision of law because both are essentially needed for each other to function.

YALA NATIONAL PARK: SHORTAGE OF EMPLOYEES AND

(i) whether he is aware of the problems relating to the shortage of employees, housing facilities for employees and facilities such as tourist bungalows, toilet facilities, roads network and common amenities in the Yala National Park;
(ii) the number of registered tourist jeeps that are allowed to enter the park;
(iii) the number of jeeps registered, but not currently providing services to tourists;
(iv) the action that will be taken regarding those jeeps;
(v) whether steps will be taken to register new jeeps to replace the jeeps concerned; and

(vi) separately, the short-term, medium-term, and long-term measures that will be taken to protect and develop the wildlife and the ecosystem in the Yala National Park, which has secured significant tourist attraction and attention and generates a substantial daily income for Sri Lanka?

: DILAPIDATED HOLIDAY RESORTS IN VICINITY OF DEDURU
() , ? asked the Minister of Agriculture, Livestock, Land and Irrigation:

(a) Will he inform this House - (i) whether he is aware that there are lands coming under the purview of the Irrigation Department located in the vicinity of Deduru Oya of the Yapahuwa Kingdom; (ii) whether expeditious measures will be taken to renovate the holiday resorts built on the lands concerned, which are now falling into disrepair; (iii) whether the Irrigation Department has a course of action to provide sanitary facilities to the area concerned since local tourists make use of the area for recreational purposes and nevertheless no sanitary facilities are available; (iv) whether the Irrigation Department has a plan to improve the conditions of the Ridibendi Ella anicut area together with the holiday resorts in order to attract local and foreign tourists; and (v) whether steps will be taken to overcome the obstacles to agricultural activities owing to poor drainage of irrigated water, due to existence of several irregular constructions in the aforesaid area?
() ( ) ( () - ) (The Hon. (Dr.) Susil Ranasinghe - Deputy Minister of Land and Irrigation) 9 99 9.
asked the Minister of Agriculture, Livestock, Land and Irrigation:
(i) the number of major irrigation reservoirs existing in Sri Lanka;
(ii) whether the reservation boundaries of the reservoirs concerned have been identified;
(iii) if so, the number of reservoirs in which reservation boundaries have been identified;
(iv) whether the identified reservation boundaries of the reservoirs have been gazetted; and
(v) the reservoirs of which reservation boundaries had been gazetted?
(b) Will he also inform this House -
(i) the number of families living within the reservation boundary of the Nuwara Weva Reservoir in the Anuradhapura District;
(ii) whether a list of names of such people will be tabled;
(iii) whether permits have been granted for lands in which they live; and
(iv) if so, whether a list of people who have been granted with a permit will be presented?
( ) (The Hon. Speaker) . ( ) (The Hon. Susantha Kumara Nawarathna) 9 9 9. . 9 9 9. 9 9 9 9.
: DRINKING WATER SCHEMES COMMENCED IN ESTATE
) (The Hon. Darmapriya Wijesinghe on behalf of the Hon.
asked the Minister of Plantation and Community Infrastructure:

(a) Is he aware that the - (i) people of the plantation sector have been faced with immense difficulties due to lack of clean drinking water since the previous governments did not commence drinking water schemes in those areas; and (ii) UNICEF commenced the Plantation Sector Drinking Water Scheme in 1987?

(b) Will he inform this House - (i) the number of Plantation Sector Drinking Water Schemes commenced by the UNICEF; (ii) the names of the districts and the plantation estates in which the schemes concerned were commenced; (iii) whether those schemes are functioning at present; and (iv) the current situation of each of the aforesaid schemes, separately?
(c) Will he also inform this House of the - (i) number of drinking water schemes that were implemented in the estate areas in the Badulla District during the past five (05) years;

(ii) amount of money that had been allocated for the said schemes; (iii) amount of money that had been allocated for the drinking water scheme which has been implemented to supply water to the LLG Capkade New Housing Scheme in Poonagala, in the Haldummulla Divisional Secretary's Division; and (iv) present status of the drinking water scheme concerned?
( ) ( - ) (The Hon. Sundaralingam Pradeep - Deputy Minister of Plantation and Community Infrastructure) 9 99 * 9.
) ( - ) (The Hon. Sivagnanam Shritharan on behalf of the Hon. Gnanamuththu Srineshan) 9 9 9 9 - (
asked the Minister of Transport, Highways, Ports and Civil Aviation:

(i) severe adverse effect has been caused to transport and economic activities of people living in the territory which has been split in twain as Eluwankarai and Paduwankarai because of the lagoon situated in the Batticaloa District; and
(ii) need has arisen to erect bridges in order to solve the transport problems faced by the people concerned?
(i) the difficulties faced by the people of the Batticaloa District due to bridges not being available in adequate number;
(ii) the approximate number of bridges which need to be built for overcoming the difficulties referred to above;
(iii) the areas through which those bridges will be constructed;
(iv) whether action will be taken to construct at least two of the bridges lined up, using the Budgetary allocations for the year 2025 and international donations; and
(v) the social and economic benefits that will be accrued to people in the Batticaloa District by the construction of bridges?

Economic challenges across the world would not help the country at any given time. Therefore, we need to formulate a macroeconomic policy that stabilizes the Sri Lankan economy, considering the realities we face on a
day-to-day basis. 9 9 9 9 9 9. 9 9 9 - importers exporters - 9 9 9 99 9 9 99 contribution 9 9 99 9. 9 9 9 . 9 9 9 9 . 9. 99 open LCs 9. 9 9 9 9 99 . 9 9 fleet 9 9 9 9 importation 9. 9 9 9 .

Amidst global challenges, Hon. Speaker, we are determined to make sure that we provide, with timely interventions and necessary discussions with the appropriate parties relating to global challenges, the necessary facilitation for our business community, the private sector and particularly to the SME sector of the country, ensuring that adequate financing is available to them and that they are able to access financing at an affordable level. Sir, that is a very important step. During the time the current Government has been managing the economy, the interest rate of the country has stabilized and it came to a single-digit level on many occasions. With this reduction of rates, we would like particularly the State banks and, of course, the private banks also to provide the necessary assistance, the push and support to the SME sector, to this vulnerable segment of the business community.

In addition to that, Sir, inflation has been contained continuously, allowing consumers to access necessary items at an affordable price. That is not the best practice, considering the level of prices that was there earlier. We try to find out what amendments, what changes and facilitations needs to be done to increase that accessibility.
() ( () ) (The Hon. (Dr.) Harshana Suriyapperuma) I will take one more minute, Sir.

To ensure producer competitiveness, we need to make sure that our exporters are able to export goods at a competitive rate. By making sure that the required dollar income is brought into the country, we would be able to repay our debt. We are sitting on a mountain of debt due to the bad and wrong economic policies adopted and borrowings made at commercial rates by the previous governments, who are now preaching to us from the other side. We need to ensure that this issue is contained and a solution is provided for. Therefore, the current Government has implemented many necessary solutions, considering the global context as well. I am sure we would be able to explain more during the Debate.
Thank you very much, Sir, for the time allotted. ( ) (The Hon. Speaker) 9 9 .00 9 9 9.

( ) (The Hon. Deputy Speaker) The Hon. Shanakiyan Rajaputhiran Rasamanickam. You have 13 minutes.
( ) (The Hon. Shanakiyan Rajaputhiran Rasamanickam) Hon. Deputy Speaker, . , 16 . . . .

I would like to acknowledge one thing that the Hon. President said in his speech yesterday. He, at least, mentioned that it is not only the mothers from the South who are grieving the death of their soldier sons, but also the Tamil mothers in the North and the East over their loved ones lost in the last stages of the war. So, I would like to acknowledge what the Hon. President went on to say at the war memorial, the victory memorial or whatever event.

Then, the Hon. President mentioned about celebrating a Sri Lanka Day; I think it was in the Budget Speech that he mentioned that a new day is going to be allocated for all Sri Lankans to get together and celebrate being Sri Lankan. I think that event can be scrapped now. We do not need that event anymore because it is very clear - on the 18th of May, the Tamil people remembered their dead loved ones and continued the call for justice for those who were killed, those they lost at the hands of the army while the Hon. President commemorated the so-called war heroes of the South on the 19th of May - that there is a division between the Tamil nation and the Sinhala nation. On the 18th, the Tamil nation were on the streets remembering their loved ones who were killed; the Hon. President, on the other hand, held commemoration of war heroes on the 19th. So, Hon. Deputy Speaker, at your Group Meeting or whatever, when you get the opportunity, tell the Hon. President that any more funds need not be raised to create a fake Sri Lanka Day as, clearly, there is a division in the country.

Having said that, Sir, there is one other matter I would like to raise in this House. That is about the land issue. I saw in the morning both the Hon. Minister in charge of agriculture and the Hon. Prime Minister engaging in exchanges of words about this Gazette issued regarding settlement of land in the Northern Province. Now, I would like to read out something that Mr. M. A. Sumanthiran has shared on his Facebook page about that Gazette. The Hon. Minister of Justice is also present here. Mr. M. A. Sumanthiran is a very senior, recognized and respected lawyer and I know that your President also sought his legal advice before he became President. I do not know if he still does that. So, on his Facebook, Mr. Sumanthiran has specifically mentioned about this Gazette. He has mentioned it in Tamil and let me read it out.
( ) (The Hon. Deputy Speaker) Hon. Member, your time is up.

GAZETTE NOTIFICATION NO. 2430/2025 ON SETTLEMENT OF
.. ( .. ) (The Hon. G.G. Ponnambalam) Hon. Presiding Member, I move the following Adjournment Motion:

By Gazette Notification bearing number 2430/2025 dated 28.03.2025, settlement notices totalling seven in number (Numbered from 5617 to 5623) for the Districts of Jaffna, Mullaitivu, Kilinochchi and Mannar covering more than 5,000 acres has been published.

The said notifications attempt to take over land including beaches, lakes, cart lanes and cemeteries - land that was used by the Tamil people from time immemorial as res communes - and convert them into State land.

The Tamil struggle for self-determination originated inter alia in response to the alienation of State land by the Sri Lankan State with the explicit intent of changing the demographics of the North-East, through which the Sri Lankan State attempts and continues to attempt to make the Tamils a minority in their own homeland. The Tamils have consistently maintained that their autonomous institutions must have control over State land in the North-East.
The above Gazette Notification is another initiative in the long history of depriving the Tamils of their homeland by successive Sri Lankan Governments.

Furthermore, our understanding is that the land sought to be declared includes private lands which those private owners have difficulty establishing ownership owing to loss of documentation during the tsunami and repeated displacements.

This Government in its manifesto, both at the Presidential Elections of 2024 and the General Elections of 2025, promised to genuinely explore a constitutional settlement to the National Question which includes settling the question of who controls State land. However, this act on the part of the Government makes clear that their views are no different to the previous governments in relation to control of the State land. The Tamil people see this action on the part of the Government as yet another act of structural genocide of the Tamil nation.
I urge that the Government immediately withdraw this Gazette Notification.
Sir, I am the Mover of this Motion, but you have given me only six minutes.

.. ( .. ) (The Hon. G.G. Ponnambalam) - ( ) (The Hon. Presiding Member) . 9 . .. ( .. ) (The Hon. G.G. Ponnambalam) 2 . ( ) (The Hon. Presiding Member) . .. ( .. ) (The Hon. G.G. Ponnambalam) 9. .

Hon. Minister, with the motives you have just stated, we would have no problems. But, the law you are trying to use has the completely opposite intention. So, if your intention is actually not to pronounce the lands you have demarcated, those 6,000 acres, as State land, this is not the law to use. What we are suggesting is what you have suggested doing with regard to land for wildlife and forestry. You appoint a committee or a commission, we will cooperate.

We accept that there are severe problems with regard to land, which need to be sorted out. Because of displacements, multiple displacements, and the tsunami, people do not have documents. That has to be resolved. We will cooperate with you, but please do not use this land. I do not know who has advised you, Hon. Minister. But, this land are going to be acquired to make them State land; it is to declare them State land. You talk about suspending this Gazette, but you cannot suspend it. Once the Gazette is issued by the 28th of June, this land will vest as State land, if they are not claimed. You cannot suspend the Gazette. I do not know on what legal advice you are making this position in this House. You cannot suspend it; you have to revoke it.

And, I assure you, Hon. Minister, that you will have our cooperation in sorting out the problems of our people. I mean, why would we not want our peoples problems be solved, whether it is your Government or any other government in power? But, I am telling you with utmost responsibility, you are using the wrong law to do that. On the contrary, this law, by the 28th of June, will declare all those 6,000-odd acres you have demarcated as State land. So, I kindly urge you to withdraw this Gazette. I assure you that all the Hon. Members seated on this side of the House belonging to the North-East, the Tamil Members, will cooperate with you. It is in our interest to solve the

land issues which have been plaguing our people because they have lost documents. So, we understand the issue. But, this is not the way - you are frightening us and not even the Rajapaksas did this - to go about it.

And, if you actually want to solve this problem, you should have had a word with us. You have given just three months! If we did not bring this out into the open, those private citizens who are supposed to make claims to these land would not have even known about this. You tell me, what is the effort you made in order to draw public awareness to this Gazette? If we did not make it a controversy, nobody would have known about it! So, kindly understand, this is not the way to go about it. You are frightening us. You must withdraw this Gazette. We will cooperate with you; if the intention is actually to solve the problems, you can be assured that we would cooperate.
It being past 5.30 p.m. THE HON. PRESIDING MEMBER adjourned Parliament without Question put.
Parliament adjourned accordingly at 6.00 p.m. until 9.30 a.m. on Wednesday, 21st May, 2025.
Corrections which Members suggest for the Final Print should be clearly marked in their copy and sent to the Editor of HANSARD within two weeks
of receipt of the uncorrected copy.
